stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on the 11th course, an oil rig, focusing on a mission where the player pranks Koopa workers. He implemented the physics and interactions for breaking a glass pane, designed and modeled a Wiggler overseer character while balancing creative ideas with polygon limits, and discussed the level's music with chat. He also briefly showcased a separate, recently completed project, "Only Up 64."

development_findings.summary: For a glass-breaking effect, Kaze decided against a complex particle system or numerous pieces, instead opting to hard-code an animation of two large pieces falling to save significant development effort.
development_findings.quote: we're just gonna fake it so we don't actually have to write a physics simulation

development_findings.summary: A creative idea to put hard hats on each of a Wiggler's body segments was scrapped because the resulting model exceeded the N64's polygon budget, demonstrating a direct conflict between a creative idea and technical limitations.
development_findings.quote: a thousand triangles is too much. Can't waste my polygon budget like that.

development_findings.summary: Kaze removed a planned mission objective involving an oil barrel because he deemed it too cryptic and not comedic enough, replacing it with a more character-driven Wiggler overseer.
development_findings.quote: I think this mission would be better for trolls... I think oil guy is gone.

development_findings.summary: For his side project "Only Up 64," Kaze implemented a custom anti-cheat system that detects the use of save states by checking for memory desynchronization, locking the game if cheating is found.
development_findings.quote: I detect whether the EP ROM desyncs from the memory state

development_findings.summary: Kaze decided to add a non-essential, hidden Wing Cap to the level, believing that such secrets contribute to a game's replayability and charm, similar to the original Super Mario 64.
Kaze mentioned that he will have to re-export most of the game's assets once upcoming "fast64 improvements" are integrated into his workflow.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes his game design philosophy has matured; he now prioritizes spending more time in the design phase before implementation, unlike his process for earlier projects like "Last Impact".
context_findings.quote: when I made Last Impact I spent maybe 5% of the time designing and 95% of the time working, but I should have been spending at least 20% of the time designing.

context_findings.summary: Kaze advocates for a hybrid control scheme using a controller in the left hand for analog movement and a mouse in the right hand for precise aiming, believing it's the optimal setup for shooters.
context_findings.quote: Controller plus mouse is the future.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has a strong aversion to 2D platformers, primarily due to control schemes he considers outdated, such as using an analog stick that emulates an 8-direction D-pad.
context_findings.quote: I touched the control stick and I instantly stopped playing the game because the control stick was an emulated d-pad. I decided this is not worth it.

context_findings.summary: Kaze shared a personal anecdote about being negatively stereotyped in Germany after shaving his head, which is why he is now reluctant to go bald even in hot weather.
context_findings.quote: Dude, I did that once and everyone thought I was being a Nazi because I was bald. And usually when you're bald in German, people think you're being a Nazi.

context_findings.summary: Kaze works a remote day job as a programmer for Gears for Breakfast, where he is currently doing a lot of optimization work on an unannounced game.
Kaze created and submitted a separate project, "Only Up 64," to a competition, indicating a practical willingness to engage in side projects for financial incentives.

biobak.summary: Biobak was not present during the stream. Kaze jokingly suggested making an Andrew Tate theme song into "the Biobak theme song" to tease him, hinting at their team's internal humor.
biobak.quote: How come Biobak's not here? This would be like his theme song.

badub.summary: Badub has created a work-in-progress soundtrack for the oil rig level. Kaze describes the desired atmosphere as "grimy but also kind of comedic."
Badub is also porting and remixing a "Yoshi's Island night theme" for an 8-bit section of the game.

zeina.summary: Zeina stated that the new Wiggler character will be the most complex animation task in the project so far, due to its multiple segments and bones.
zeina.quote: He's gonna be the most difficult one to animate yet. I thought Bowser was difficult enough, this is gonna be even worse.

zeina.summary: Zeina actively contributes to design and modeling decisions during the stream, such as pointing out a hole in the penguin model and suggesting improvements for the Wiggler's boots.
Zeina is working on animations for the game, including for a baby penguin character, while Kaze codes.

key_stories.title: Designing the Wiggler Overseer
key_stories.summary: Kaze replaced an unintuitive mission objective with a new Wiggler overseer character. During the design process, a comedic idea to put hard hats on all its body segments was scrapped because the resulting polygon count was too high for the N64, showing the direct conflict between creative ambition and technical limitations.
key_stories.challenge: An objective where the player had to kick an oil barrel to make a Koopa slip was deemed unintuitive and not funny enough to be worth implementing.
key_stories.process: Kaze identified the weakness in the oil barrel idea and decided to cut it. He brainstormed a replacement, settling on a Wiggler character. He and Zeina then collaborated on its visual design, modeling it with themed boots and a hard hat, but had to simplify it to meet technical constraints.
key_stories.outcome: The oil barrel idea was scrapped. It was replaced with a Wiggler overseer character who gets progressively angrier as the player completes other objectives. A comedic visual gag for the Wiggler (hats on all segments) was also prototyped but cut due to the polygon budget.
key_stories.key_quote: I think we can't do this. I'm going to build more tanks in the weakness segments because that looks awful.

key_stories.title: Faking the Physics of Shattering Glass
key_stories.summary: Kaze needed to create an effect for breaking a glass pane. He considered complex solutions but ultimately chose a simpler, "faked" physics animation to save significant development time while still being effective. This illustrates his pragmatic approach to balancing visual flair with workload.
key_stories.challenge: How to create a convincing glass-shattering effect for a pane carried by two Koopas without creating a massive amount of work through a physics simulation or importing many small models.
key_stories.process: Kaze considered multiple approaches, including a particle effect or breaking the glass into many small, physics-driven pieces. He rejected these as too labor-intensive. He decided to simply split the existing model into two halves and animate their fall manually, then coded the Koopas' reactions and dialogue.
key_stories.outcome: A simple but effective interaction was created. The glass pane splits into two large, pre-defined pieces with a hard-coded falling animation. This achieved the desired visual effect while being extremely efficient from a development standpoint.
key_stories.key_quote: we're just gonna fake it so we don't actually have to write a physics simulation

key_stories.title: The Anti-Save State System
key_stories.summary: For a competition, Kaze created "Only Up 64," an extremely difficult game. To fit the "troll" theme, he implemented a system to detect the use of save states, which would then lock the player's controls. This demonstrates his technical skill and playful approach to game design.
key_stories.challenge: For a "troll hack" competition, Kaze wanted to create a game that was not only difficult but also actively punished players for using common tools like save states to bypass the difficulty.
key_stories.process: Kaze identified that players would use save states to beat his difficult level. He devised a technical solution to detect when the console's EPROM data desynchronizes from the game's memory state, a clear indicator of a save state being loaded. He then tied this detection to a trigger that disables player controls.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully implemented an anti-save-state feature in his game "Only Up 64." When a player loads a save state, the game detects it, displays a "no cheating" message, and locks all inputs, forcing a reset.
key_stories.key_quote: I detect whether the EP ROM desyncs from the memory state
